Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: New Crystallization Modifiers for Low Calorie Fats in Food Products
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project is to facilitate the commercialization of low fat replacement EPG technology to help solve some of the largest obesity and related health issues facing the US while providing a patentable new additive platform for the $600 billion food industry. With high caloric density foods being the primary cause for the obesity epidemic, the facilitation of rapid development of 92% lower calorie fat replacers such as EPG will have a powerful impact on the health of a large portion of society, reducing health care cost for US citizens and providing a positive economic impact for the US. The highest initial impact will be the introduction of additive modified EPG fat replacers to the confectionary segment where the need for decreased caloric content is greatest due to the absence of compatible low-calorie fats. Locally, the development of this technology will result in growth of 20 + high technology jobs in South Carolina. During Phase II, Tetramer will work with undergraduates and high school students through the NSF Phase II supplemental programs, which have trained 25 undergraduate students and 9 high school students who have all gone into STEM careers.

The objectives of this Phase II research project are to provide critically needed additive control technology to allow the dramatically reduced caloric intake (up to 92% ) of esterified propoxylated glycerol technology (EPG) to be used in many food products that today contain high calorie natural fats and oils. During Phase I activities, Tetramer discovered that the new EPG approach to mitigating the growing obesity epidemic in the US was hampered by the fact that being a new technology EPG processes differently than high calorie fats such as palm kernel oil or cocoa butter. This creates a manufacturing mismatch for a significant number of the products in the projected $2.6 Billion fat replacement market. To date the commercially available additives do not work, thus requiring a new additive molecular architecture ?toolbox? to optimize the processing variables. Tetramer will use it's synthetic organic chemistry and material science expertise to synthesize and optimize additives that will allow EPG?s to provide 92% lower calories, while still maintaining the same sensory, physical properties and processing efficiency as the natural oils they will replace. End use applications will be developed through collaborations with food industry leaders.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Data from the USDA show that average daily calorie intake has increased from 2039 in 1970 to 2544 in 2010. Breaking that data down further, the calories from added fats in foods has increased from 337 calories to 550 calories during the same timeframe. For the past 20 years, the development of low calorie fat replacers (LCFR) has been a high priority for the food industry. Unfortunately, products such as Olestra, Salatrim, Benefat and others have suffered from serious commercial shortcomings such as anal leakage, taste, poor mouth feel, and disappointing total calorie reduction. Most common fats have a calorie per gram content of 9 kcal per gram. For this Phase II, SBIR Tetramer Technologies has been focused on improving a new low calorie fat replacer technology (LCFR) that has not only a 92% reduction in fat grams (0.7 kcal per gram) but also has been shown to have no anal leakage, excellent taste and mouth feel in confectionary and spreadable commercial applications. This technology has obtained full Generally Recognized As Safe (GRAS) approval by the FDA, which is a critical certification for commercialization. In order to maximize calorie reduction it is necessary to incorporate as much LCFR as possible into a particular food formulation/recipe.

Being a new LCFR technology, the currently commercially available food additives used to economically process food products such as confectionaries are not effective. This situation creates a manufacturing process barrier to be solved in order to enable faster commercialization. The primary focus of this Phase II SBIR research program has been the elimination of the process barrier, through the development of a crystal modifier technology platform enabling incorporation of this new LCFR technology into a wide variety of food applications such as confectionary, spreadables, baking, and frying oils.

During this Phase II SBIR research program, Tetramer developed a patent pending modifier technology platform for the LCFR technology across multiple food applications. The efficacy of the modifier in applications from confectionery to frying oils has been clearly demonstrated. Tetramer also modified this technology to utilize current industrial fats and oils processes for the large-scale production of the modifier technology, making this a cost-effective tailored modifier for the LCFR technology. In talks with various end users and fats/oils manufacturers Tetramer observed significant interest in its modifier platform as it allows the LCFR technology to behave as a drop-in replacement for current fats in multiple food applications.

This fundamental understanding of how various fats interact with each other and the new LCFR technology will allow Tetramer and food product customers the ability to design and develop crystal modifiers that allow for maximum calorie reduction in food products thanks to increased inclusion of LCFRs in food product formulations. The combination of a very large market driven by the need to reduce obesity creates a powerful commercial value proposition.
